body: A day after former State Senator Carl Kruger tearfully pleaded guilty to corruption charges, the campaigning to replace him began on Wednesday, with Republicans hoping for a rare victory in New York City and Democrats eager to hold the seat. The state's top elected Republican, Dean G. Skelos of Long Island, the Senate majority leader, and dozens of
title: G.O.P. Is Hopeful as Race to Replace Senator Takes Shape

body: Mary Rodriguez, a diabetic widow, greeted a visitor recently without an umbrella in the rain outside the maze of brick buildings in the Brooklyn housing project where she lived. Her legs were swollen, and her flip-flops were drenched. She wobbled back in while mentioning she owned a walker. Ms. Rodriguez led the way through Marlboro Houses into
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Serving the Role of a Loving Mother to Her 'Little Monster'

body: A heady perfume of cheese, tomatoes and crispy coal-fired crust wafts onto the sidewalk of Old Fulton Street, intoxicating enough to cause tourists to snap pictures and queue in stomach-growling anticipation. But few know the gritty, gooey story behind Grimaldi's Pizzeria, the internationally recognized Brooklyn hot spot at the center of a changing
title: CITY ROOM; A Sprinkling of Drama In the City's Pizza World

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: 'Civil Rights in Brooklyn: Stories of Struggle and Protest' (Sunday) A discussion, with archivists and audience participation, on the impact in Brooklyn of the civil rights movement, in celebration of its 50th anniversary. 128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718)
title: Spare Times

body: Two days after the sight of flaming cars and anti-Semitic graffiti horrified a heavily Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn, residents, elected officials and others took part in a march on Sunday against hatred and intolerance. The police were still investigating the burning of three parked cars on Ocean Parkway and the spray-painting of swastikas and
title: After an Anti-Semitic Episode, a March With a Message

body: Konrad Surkont is hoping to update his status on Facebook. ''I want it to include the word dynasty,'' said Surkont, a senior at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan who is the top cross-country runner in the Public Schools Athletic League. ''If we want to be a true dynasty, we need to win another city championship.'' Stuyvesant -- which has won four
title: Elite Runners From Elite Schools Vie for a Title

body: BOONTON, N.J. -- When dusk descended here last Sunday, and the forum on domestic violence was over, some 200 people carrying candles marched up the hilly street to where Nazish Noorani had been killed exactly two months earlier in a shooting the police said had been set up by her husband. By the time of the vigil, Ms. Noorani's two young sons were
title: After Arrest of Man in Wife's Death, a Custody Fight

body: WASSERMAN--Bernice S.,85, of Brooklyn Heights, died October 14. Dearly beloved wife of Dr. Bernard, cherished mother of Harvey and Kim and Andrew and Donna; loving grandmother of Jake and Sarah; beloved aunt, cousin and friend. Graduate of Erasmus High School and Hunter College, she worked for Science Magazine. She was an avid supporter of the arts
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WASSERMAN, BERNICE S.

body: WASSERMAN--Bernice S.,85, of Brooklyn Heights, died October 14. body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

body: Rachel Ann Markowitz and Joshua Alan Krupitsky are to be married Sunday at the Wainwright House, an alternative learning center in Rye, N.Y. Judge William F. Kuntz II of the United States District Court for Eastern New York is to officiate. The bride, 28, will take her husband's name. She is the assistant manager for academic marketing for the
title: Rachel Markowitz, Joshua Krupitsky

body: A city councilman from Brooklyn was handcuffed and briefly detained by the police on Monday afternoon during the West Indian Day Parade after an argument with officers over whether he was allowed to use a closed sidewalk, said Public Advocate Bill de Blasio, whose aide was also detained in the dispute. The councilman, Jumaane D. Williams, was not
title: Police Detain Brooklyn Councilman at West Indian Parade

body: BOONTON, N.J. -- After his wife had been shot to death on the street and he had been wounded, Kashif Parvaiz told the police here in her quiet hometown in New Jersey that three men had accosted them and, before opening fire, called them a name that is offensive to Muslims in America: ''Terrorist.'' That prompted detectives to treat the case as a
title: Husband Admits He Set Up Killing Of Wife in Street, The Police Say

body: BOONTON, N.J. -- Cyril Wekilsky, the 72-year old mayor of Boonton, said he could not recall the last shooting death before this week in his community, a small town of under 9,000 people some 30 miles from Manhattan. ''I'm scratching my head trying,'' he said. Yet on midnight Tuesday, the mayor found himself standing at the edge of a crime scene
title: Killing Shocks and Puzzles a Quiet New Jersey Town

body: KLASS--Blossom Marcus, passed away on August 5, 2011. She was to be 83 on August 20. Blossom was the devoted wife of Lionel Klass, who died on February 25, 2000. She was a gifted teacher, a world traveler, a lover of the arts, and especially of gardens. A long time resident of Midwood, Brooklyn, Blossom was an avid community activist, holding
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KLASS, BLOSSOM MARCUS

body: ONE of the most popular online inventions of New York City's government is The Daily Pothole, a blog that tracks, in gravelly detail, the milling and paving of street cavities from Midwood to Midtown. It is eye candy for the asphalt-obsessed: panoramic photos accompanied by comic captions (''Bump!'' ''Sneak Attack!'') and a goggle-eyed mascot named
title: A Digital Matchmaker For the City and Its Public

body: On a quiet street in the Ballard neighborhood of Seattle sits a cozy little restaurant on the verge of being thrust into a rather public life. Delancey, a chic yet unassuming pizzeria whose décor makes you feel as if you've walked into your hipster neighbor's dining room midmeal, is the love child of Brandon Pettit, a former New York music
title: BITES; Seattle: Delancey

body: When it showed up unannounced in April, the neighbors stared, goggle-eyed. Some compared the scene to one in a classic Stanley Kubrick film. ''The neighbors started gathering around it like it was the monolith in '2001,' '' said the Rev. Jeanne Person, an Episcopal priest who has lived in a century-old pocket of Flatbush, Brooklyn, for 11 years.
title: In an Early 1900s Neighborhood, a Glimpse of '2001'

body: When the city officially recognized Douglaston Hill in Queens as a historic district in 2004, the community celebrated. Three years later, residents of Dumbo, Brooklyn, breathed a sigh of relief when their neighborhood, too, finally won its historic designation. With landmarking, the neighborhoods' buildings would be protected by the city and all
title: CITY ROOM; A Long Wait for Historic-District Signs

body: It was a day long awaited, but Jane Kani Edward could not bring herself to fully embrace the moment. For Dr. Edward, like many of the few Sudanese immigrants living in the New York metropolitan area, July 9, the day that the Republic of South Sudan became an independent state, carried mixed emotions. She had lost her father and three brothers in
title: Pride Is Tinged With Sadness as a Nation Is Born

body: Dennis M. Walcott, New York City's schools chancellor, hates prepared texts for speeches and wears a pedometer to count his daily steps. So it stands to reason that during a 14-stop marathon of graduations over the past week, he frequently abandoned his seat and improvised. As hundreds of seniors from his alma mater, Francis Lewis High School in
title: For New Schools Chief, a Policy Statement In Warm Tones of Harmony and Stability

body: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a once-promising politician whose Brooklyn roots and scrappy style made him a leading candidate to be the next mayor of New York, resigned his seat on Thursday, ending a three-week scandal over his lewd online behavior that startled his constituents and alienated many of his colleagues. Mr. Weiner made the decision
title: IN CHAOTIC SCENE, WEINER QUITS SEAT IN SCANDAL'S WAKE

body: Heightening concerns about the value of many of its high school diplomas, the New York State Education Department released new data on Tuesday showing that only 37 percent of students who entered high school in 2006 left four years later adequately prepared for college, with even smaller percentages of minority graduates and those in the largest
title: 37 Percent of New York Graduates Are College-Ready, Data Show

body: Heightening concerns about the value of many of its high school diplomas, the New York State Education Department released new data on Tuesday showing that only 37 percent of students who entered high school in 2006 left four years later adequately prepared for college, with even smaller percentages of minority graduates and those in the largest
title: 37 Percent of New York Graduates Are College-Ready, Data Show

body: There are three million immigrants in New York City. When they left home, knowing it could be forever, they packed what they could not bear to leave behind: necessities, luxuries, memories. Here is a look at what some of them brought. SAM DOLNICK Jessica Lane, 29 CAME FROM Perth, Australia CAME IN 2010Ms. Lane, a dancer, outgrew her first pair of
title: Belongings

body: Lefferts Gardens Row House $1,600,000 BROOKLYN: 51 Midwood Street (between Flatbush and Bedford Avenues)A six-bedroom two-and-a-half-bath 1898 Lefferts Manor limestone house with an office and a landscaped garden. Susan Slater, Corcoran Group (917) 744-1454; www.corcoran.com Open house June 12, 1 to 3 p.m.TAXES: $4,832 a yearPROS: The parlor floor,
title: ON THE MARKETS

body: Marie Viljoen padded through the woods in Prospect Park one recent morning like a Brooklyn-chic bushwhacker in cargo pants, tall leather boots and a shock of red lipstick. She stepped delicately over damp logs and poison-ivy patches, a metal trash-grabber in one hand, a black trash bag in the other. Something caught her eye. ''Jackpot,'' she said.
title: CITY ROOM; Volunteers Clear Away A Park's Unsavory Bits

body: LEVITT--Mitzi. On May 28. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving and proud mother of Michael and the late Stacy. Mitzi leaves behind Maria, devoted friend and family member. A School secretary at the Rabbi Harry Halpern Day School of East Midwood Jewish Center. She was a supporter of charities and a treasured friend to many. Services Tuesday,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVITT, MITZI

body: ''We demand a recount,'' declared Assemblyman Rory I. Lancman, a Democrat from Queens. The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, pronounced himself ''flabbergasted.'' ''The numbers are dead wrong,'' said Senator Charles E. Schumer, ''and it makes you wonder if the Census Bureau is living on a different planet.'' After learning that the
title: New York City's Claim of a Census Undercount May Be Justified, Canvassing Finds

body: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul -- or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the
title: LIVING IN | SHEEPSHEAD BAY, BROOKLYN; Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure

body: In the Metropolitan cover story last week, Liz Robbins described the complex system that New York City uses to match students and high schools, the difficulties that parents and students have in navigating that system and the disappointing results experienced by 10 percent of the applicants -- applicants like Radcliffe Saddler (right), an honors
title: READER COMMENTS; Some 'Amazing' Schools, A 'Broken' Process

body: ON the last day in March, when most eighth graders in New York City learned where they would be going to high school in the fall, Radcliffe Saddler watched the majority of his classmates rip open thin envelopes and celebrate. Some students opened thick envelopes just as he did and started crying. Radcliffe, an honors student at Isaac Bildersee
title: Lost in the School Choice Maze

body: There were, of course, the joyous celebrations, the honking horns, cheering crowds and waving flags, as if war had been won and tyranny ended. But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope. As Americans streamed to the
title: A Mood of Triumph and Sober Reflection

body: GELBER--Sarah. Born November 6, 1923, passed away on April 25, 2011. Beloved wife of Hy, mother of Susan and Carrie, sister of Ben and Goldie, and loving grandmother of Zachary, Max and Nick. Sebby lived life to the fullest . . . her husband, family and dancing were her passions. Memorial service at noon April 27 at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GELBER, SARAH

body: AN unlikely hybrid of curator, hoarder, historian and D.I.Y.-er, extreme hobbyists do not just accumulate memorabilia; they define their existence by it. Occasionally, they overdo it. ''You see them all the time, people with this compulsion to collect,'' says Philip Weiss, the owner of Philip Weiss Auctions on Long Island and a frequent appraiser
title: Meet the Extreme Hobbyists

body: The big Passover questions are the same every year, and easy enough to answer, starting with ''Why is this night different from all others?'' Little questions, though, sometimes arise that can stump even the experts. Like, what to do about the quinoa situation? Quinoa (pronounced ki-NO-uh or KEEN-wah) is a grainlike South American crop newly
title: Something Tasty, Healthy, and Perfect for the Seder, Unless ...

body: IF Mitchell Zelman's customers are sorry to see him, he's not offended. ''People generally leave happy,'' Mr. Zelman said, ''but sort of with the attitude, 'I hope I don't see you for a long time.' '' And, for the sake of his reputation, he's hoping the same. Mitchell's Auto Repair, near the Borough Park-Sunset Park border in Brooklyn, is the sort
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BOROUGH PARK; Auto Repair, As an Art And a Science

body: Except for matzo, anything that's made with grain is prohibited during Passover. That means the usual spirits distilled from rye, corn or wheat are off limits. So Distillery No. 209 in San Francisco, the gin company owned by Leslie Rudd, who also owns Dean & DeLuca, is making a kosher gin with neutral spirits distilled from sugar cane (like rum).
title: FOOD STUFF; Gin and Passover: No Longer Contradictory

body: Aid for Japan and Italy To raise money for Japanese disaster relief, an eclectic concert with something for everyone will be held on Thursday at 8 p.m. at City Winery, 155 Varick Street (Vandam Street). Tickets are $45 to $65: citywinery.com. There will be food and wine for sale. On Sunday, the restaurant Gemma, 335 Bowery (Third Street), will
title: Dining Calendar

body: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and ''we took up the entire basement,'' Mr. Alvarez said. Somehow they had accumulated an array of space-hogging clothes,
title: THE HUNT; A Move Dictated by Miscellany

body: Along a freight train line that winds through Brooklyn and Queens, desolate areas are used as gathering spots or refuges for minor outlaws: graffiti painters, drug users and those who camp out with little more than a piece of cardboard, a blanket and a bottle of vodka to keep them company. In one spot, beneath an overpass on Ocean Avenue in
title: Beneath an Overpass, Hints of a Suspect's Obsession

body: A fugitive with a knife, who the police said had left behind a calamity of murders and broken lives in Brooklyn, was captured by officers at Times Square on Saturday morning after stabbing another victim on a subway train, investigators said. It was the culmination of a roller-coaster of violence that included three fatal stabbings; a hit-and-run
title: CITY ROOM; Suspect in Four Killings Is Captured in Subway

body: A 23-year-old man fatally stabbed his stepfather in Brooklyn early Friday and killed his girlfriend and her mother later in the day before commandeering a passing car, stabbing the driver, stealing the car and running down a pedestrian, the police said. The suspect, identified by the police as Maksim Gelman, remained at large on Friday night after
title: After Three Are Killed in Brooklyn Attacks, the Police Hunt for a Suspect

body: The weather and the calendar conspired on Friday to give New York City the break it had been looking for since the paralyzing blizzard that ended Monday: Temperatures reached 45 degrees, and many workers had the day off in observance of New Year's Day. Subway, bus and commuter train service had returned to normal; airports operated with minimal
title: New York Tries to Plow Its Way Back To Normal
